text: Patient: All of it. Doctor: And, so you didn’t get any kind of call from the company that did the test? Patient: No. Doctor: As far as you know? Patient: No. Doctor: Oh okay. Patient: The only e-mail that I got was a confirmation that they had received my test. Family Member: But that was the only thing, right? Not that that’s a small thing, but that was – there was no other genetic, uh, information. Doctor: Actually, I gave you the wrong information. I’m sorry. So, it’s actually a higher chance that they inherit it because it’s --- I, I forgot this is what’s called – so there’s two kinds of mutations; dominant and recessive. So, recessive means you have to, uh, uh, get, uh, two bad copies to – I want to say it’s a twenty-five percent chance because you have to get two bad copies. But, in this case, if you get one bad copy, you are at risk even though you have one good copy. So, in that case, it sort of takes out your, the mother. So, they, they have a fifty percent chance of getting this gene from you. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So, uh, so if they get it, they’re at risk, and if they don’t get it – so, it’s a fifty-fifty as opposed to a recessive where they have a fifty percent chance from you and a fifty percent chance from the mother, and they have to get two copies to have a problem. Patient: Okay. But –

text: Patient: No. Doctor: So those are things where it's like, oh, this is bad, but it's a fine line where it could be bad. So we will obsess about how are you doing? You know, is there any change? So, those are one of the things that we would check, but we give the same attention on the trial as well as off the trial. You know, if you're getting this regular chemo anyways, we'd ask you the same obsessive questions- Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: How are your feet or your hands. You know what your quality of life, are you losing too much weight, you know, is it too rapid of a weight loss? Are you- you know most people are not nauseous and they don’t throw up, but there's always one in a group you know- are you having problems with that or are your bowels, so we would go down the line like that like we do for Xtandi. And of course now that Xtandi's not working, stop the Xtandi because it's just losses you know kind of drive at the moment, but it's something to consider for later, so we do sometimes go back. Family Member: You're saying Xtandi- Doctor: Mhmm. Family Member: -so he would continue to take the Xtandi along with the chemo? Doctor: No, we would stop it. Family Member: Okay, then I was gonna say I kind of misinterpreted that. Doctor: Yeah, we just stop the Xtandi. Patient: Continue it until I start the trial? Doctor: Nope, you just stop it. It's not doing its thing. If you want to do the trial, or if you're okay with chemo as the next step. But either way Xtandi’s not doing it. So we need to bail out of that. It's just giving you side effects with no gain. Family Member: So how soon would you try to start the new treatment

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - to go to humans, human trials, but, uh, unless, unless your pain is getting substantially worse, in which case I would strongly encourage you to do the chemo, because that’s going to work the fastest. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Unless the pain is clearly getting worse, and if I feel that we have like a window of opportunity, where, you know, maybe the hasn’t worked but your cancer is not bad enough that you need chemotherapy right this second, then that might be like an opportunity to try a second trial. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But if I truly believe that this pain is escalating or you’re having, you know, more bad days than good days, or, you know, you’re really not able to sleep for more than like an hour at a time because you’re waking up because of back pain, those types of things would certainly lead me towards maybe chemotherapy as the next step, and perhaps reserving that clinical trial for after the chemotherapy is over. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Because that also would be a possibility, i.e., come off the trial, do some chemotherapy with the K___ oncologist, and then on the back end, when the chemotherapy is over, come back and do a different clinical trial at that point. Patient: Um hum. Okay. Okay. Okay. And, again, that’s one of the reasons why I wanted to come here, uh, uh, from the um perspective of the options. And, uh, and I, I, maybe I shouldn’t say this because your recorder is here, but I do like, not only the professionalism here, but, I, I like the sense of, uh, caring that the personnel here, uh, express. That’s from everybody within the building when you, when you come in. But the other thing is, when I come here to get lab work done, uh, I only get stuck one time. You know? I don’t like to be a big pincushion and you’ve gotten stuck four or five times, and the person still hasn’t hit the vein. Can I try your other arm? And I’m thinking like, come on, now. This, this reminds me of the time when I was in the Marine Corp. The corpsman do the stuff on purpose. You know? Doctor: Okay. Patient: So it is what it is. But I said that to say the quality of care and the compassion I can see here at J___ H___. I’m not saying it’s not there at K___. There’s some good doctors there, good personnel, that have been very helpful to me. Uh, but, uh, I see it all through the building here when I come here. That’s one thing. I could see it. Doctor: So are we all on the same page now?

text: Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Uhm and you’re in remission unless it recurs, comes back. Family Member: Uh hum. Patient: Last question, or uh maybe not. Mistletoe. I’ve had some friends that have said maybe that can help with side effects, things of that nature. If I were to research that, would that in any way – Doctor: Yeah, well thanks for asking that, so mistletoe is contraindicated certainly during chemo. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because it interferes with chem. I would say also during radiation. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: The reason is so you know everybody wants to be helpful and you know give you all kinds of natural products and things like mistletoe or kabuki mushrooms or whatever. The problem is that a lot of them are antioxidants. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So they’re really good stuff, except when you’re trying to kill bad things, and then they interfere because one of the things we’re trying to do in chemo is make reactive oxygen species which kill, make the DNA not work and breaks up and then the cells break up. If you give a medicine like mistletoe to interfere with the creation of those uh you know, what’s basically hydrogen peroxide that kills ah the cells, then you’re interfering with chemotherapy and radiation therapies. Family Member: The effectiveness of the chemo Patient: So that would be something . Uh nutrition – Then I’m scheduled to speak with someone from a company out of Colorado called

text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And my recommendation to do that would be a little bit stronger if the cancer is visible – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - on the scan, especially if it has progressed. And the recommendation would be weaker; in other words, I would be open to delaying the hormone therapy a bit longer if the cancer cannot be seen. Patient: Okay. Doctor: In other words if it’s just the PSA rising and the absence of any visible cancer on the scan. Patient: At what point would you do the scan? Is it when it goes above one? Doctor: When it goes above one. Patient: And that would be here at JH? Doctor: I would recommend that; it’s not absolutely necessary. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Typically you can do everything in one single day. Patient: Uh huh.

text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We may, I don’t think we have an opening at Hospital B but that’s one of the sites that we collaborate with, and I think they had interest in opening it, and so we can check in to see whether they have that open. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But that would be clearly if we say I’m doing chemotherapy, do I want to do something more on top of it, so that would be one option. Experimentally we have two treatments, uh one based on the fact that your ARV7 is positive. We have an experimental study where we give everyone immune therapy, a doublet. That is a combination of two drugs that are approved in melanoma, soon to be approved in kidney cancer that can turn on your immune system to attack your cancer. It doesn’t work all that well so far in prostate cancer, maybe fifteen percent of people may get a benefit. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Uh some data that said people who are on Enzalutamide stay on Enzalutamide and get these drugs uh may have a higher response rate, and that’s what we are testing. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We have done this already in fifteen men and I think three people benefited for a period of time, relatively short. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But still benefited and so they did not have Enzalutamide or the Xtandi, so we’re doing fifteen more who have Xtandi uh and seeing whether or not it’s a higher response because of that.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: So you know with you, you know what I worry about is sometimes you know, we write prostate cancer on the order form so the doctor over says, “Oh, yeah, there it is, there it is.” Patient: Okay. Doctor: And they may be right, or they may be calling what we normally if you had a scan and they’d say, “ that’s just arthritis, that’s just arthritis, that’s just arthritis”. Patient: Right. Doctor: Prostate Cancer likes to go to the lymph nodes, and so they're oft- they have to start small. And so we all have lymph nodes, but in this case, they say yeah, there’s lymph nodes- Patient: Right. Doctor: -there's a lot of them, so that could be cancer. Patient: Right. DOC. They didn't say it was cancer. It could be cancer. Doctor: The stuff in your back Two different modes of how we look at your back are telling us different things about different places. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So the tiebreaker really would be to get another test.

So, does that make sense to try that and go that route? I mean, or is it really you want to think about it more – uh, step back and again talk to your doctor about the chemo again? Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
